1.12.text:
Hello. My name is Emma, and in today's lesson,
I am going to teach you my top tips for the

13.49.text:
So, before I teach you these tips, you might
be wondering: "What's the IELTS listening

19.05.text:
module?" Well, the IELTS is a test and one
part of the test is listening. So, in the

25.54.text:
listening section, you're going to have 40
questions where you're going to listen to

32.75.text:
some conversations for about 30 minutes, and
then you'll have 10 minutes to transfer your

39.99.text:
answers over to another sheet. So, in total,
it's 40 minutes; 30 minutes for listening,

45.36.text: 10 minutes for writing down your answers.

48.10.text:
Okay, now this part of the IELTS is very possible
to get a high mark, especially if you follow

55.83.text:
my tips. All right? Now, before we get started,
I just want to let you know: I know you can

61.96.text:
do the IELTS. I know you can pass, I know
you can get a great mark, a great bandwidth

66.85.text:
- you just have to have confidence in yourself
and you have to practice. Practice, practice,

72.60.text:
practice; it really pays off.
So let's get started.

77.69.text:
So, my first tip: write no more than three words.
What do I mean by this? I don't mean

85.17.text:
for the whole thing, write no more than three words.
On the IELTS, you will have to read

91.24.text:
the instruction of what to do. Often times,
the instruction, before you listen, you're

98.61.text:
going to see: "Write no more than three words."
This is an example of an instruction you must

104.36.text:
follow. One mistake a lot of students make
during the IELTS is they don't read instructions

110.74.text:
properly. They're nervous, they're stressed
out, they write whatever, they don't... They

117.53.text:
don't follow the instructions. If you see
something like: "Write no more than three

123.30.text:
words." Do that. You can't write four, don't write five.
Write three or less. Okay? So

134.77.text:
my main point here: follow
the instructions carefully.

140.17.text:
Point number two: get used to British English. A
large part of the IELTS, you will be listening...

148.10.text:
For... For... Sorry, for the listening, you
will be listening to British accents. Sometimes

153.23.text:
you might hear Australian accents or Canadian,
you might hear a range, but a lot of the accents

158.65.text:
will be British. So it's very important to
get used to listening to British accents.

164.65.text:
And also, listen to other accents like Canadian,
Australian; that's a good idea too. Where

171.13.text:
can you find British accents to listen to? I
recommend the BBC. They have a lot of great

177.47.text:
videos there and most of it's with British
accents, so it's a very good idea so you can

184.14.text:
practice listening. The more you practice
listening with British accents, the easier

189.95.text:
it will be to understand British speakers.
Especially if you're used to American English,

197.34.text: this is a very good thing to do.

201.06.text:
Related to this point: British vocab. You
should learn British vocabulary. For example:

210.07.text:
in American English and Canadian English, we say: "truck".
In British English, we say:

216.02.text:
"lorry". So it's good to know some of these
British expressions, some British words. One

223.63.text:
idea where you can practice these is if you
check out our website: www.engvid.com, we

230.51.text:
have a new teacher who is British and who
will be talking about British English, so

235.85.text:
check out her... Her videos. It will also be
good to help you with practicing listening

245.70.text:
Number four: spelling counts. Okay? Very important.
The listening part of the IELTS is not just

255.41.text:
listening; you're actually using other skills
like writing and reading. Now, with writing,

261.98.text:
when you write down your answers, you sometimes
have to spell something out, so you have to

266.47.text:
be very, very careful with spelling. Okay?
This is something you should really study

271.72.text:
and practice before you take the listening
part of the IELTS. Practice your spelling.

278.08.text:
Learn spelling rules. We have a lot of different
videos on how to spell on engVid, so I would

284.53.text: come and check those ones out.

287.83.text:
Number five - this is the thing that always
gets my students and I always warn them about

293.71.text:
when we practice - plural versus singular. Okay?
You have to listen carefully on whether

302.85.text:
you're writing down the plural with an "s"
or the singular. If the question wants me

312.34.text:
to write down: "cat", someone's talking about their
cat and I write down: "cats", it's incorrect.

318.25.text:
I would get an "X". Okay, so it's important to
be careful, to really listen: is it a singular

327.14.text:
thing, is it a plural thing? Are they
saying "store" or "stores"? Okay?

335.57.text:
Number six - this is probably the most obvious
tip, but - very important to do practice tests.

344.08.text:
There are many, many books out there on the
IELTS that have practice tests with a CD.

350.50.text:
You can listen and you can practice. The more
you do, the better, and the better your mark

355.41.text:
probably will be. Okay? So do as many practice
tests as you can for the listening. And again,

362.10.text:
maybe when you start, it will be very difficult.
Maybe you'll do a test and you'll do very

367.60.text:
poorly on it - a practice test - it's good to keep going.
Even if you do bad at first,

374.84.text:
I'm sure the more you practice, the more you
get used to these accents - you're going to

379.89.text:
do fine. Okay? Just keep practicing,
practicing, practicing.

385.11.text:
Number seven: prediction. It's very important on the IELTS.
During the listening, at the

393.33.text:
end of each section, you have some time to
check your answers and to read the questions

400.23.text:
that are coming up. Very important that you look ahead.
Okay? Any time you have a chance

406.89.text:
to stop and to... to read ahead on the IELTS, the...
the listening part, it's very important

412.73.text:
to do this. The reason is you can make a guess,
you can predict... It's not exactly a guess,

419.82.text:
but you can predict what an answer is going
to be, and your chance of getting that answer

424.08.text:
right is going to go up. So, for example,
maybe this is one of the questions:

430.67.text:
"The woman will travel on __________." Okay,
so I'm going to have to listen to the

436.29.text:
CD. Now, what I can do is in pencil, I can
just write in what I think it's going to be.

441.67.text:
Well, I see the word: "travel", "travel on",
so maybe she's travelling on a bus, or maybe

450.55.text:
a plane. Okay. Think of some... some things
she might be travelling on. And then you can

455.46.text:
just write quickly what your prediction is.
And then, when they actually play the... the

460.42.text:
tape, listen, see if your prediction was correct.
If it's not, you can just write in the correct

467.25.text:
answer. But you'll have a good chance of getting
the answer right. The listening goes very

472.81.text:
quickly so it's very good to do this prediction
so you can prepare yourself. Know what they're

479.01.text:
looking for. Okay.
Prediction, very important.

483.42.text:
Now, let's learn some other tips to
succeed on this part of the test.

488.97.text:
Okay, my next tip is about predicting again.
But if you can't predict the word - maybe

497.14.text:
there's not enough information - at least you
can predict if they're looking for a noun,

502.59.text:
adjective, adverb, or verb. Okay, so what's
an example of this? I come over here. For

510.13.text:
the fill in the blank questions,
maybe it will say something like:

514.73.text:
"She has three __________." Okay, she
has three, what? I have no idea;

520.83.text:
she could have three of anything. But what I
do know is this is going to be... What is

527.48.text:
it going to be? Is it going to be a verb? No.
Adjective? No. It's going to be a noun.

536.37.text:
Keyword: "She has", there's already a verb
here, I know it's going to be a noun. So that

545.35.text:
Next tip. This is one of the challenging things
about the IELTS, you're listening and writing

551.85.text:
at the same time. Okay? So, again, the listening
is not only a listening; it's also listening,

558.89.text:
writing, reading, not speaking. So it's important
that you practice these skills together. What

567.93.text:
you can do is you can maybe go on the BBC,
listen to what they're saying, take notes.

575.92.text:
Get used to writing quickly while you're listening.
I think this is one of the most important

583.49.text:
Number 10 - this is the trick on the IELTS -
be aware of changes. Often times, they have

591.93.text:
a phone conversation in the listening and
somebody says something like: "Oh, the number,

598.25.text:
it's 2078." And so you write: "2078". But
then they say: "Oh, no, wait. I'm sorry. It's

605.53.text:
actually 4078." So you have to be very careful
because often times, they will give information

614.77.text:
and then they will change it. They will say: "Oh, I'm sorry.
That's the wrong information.

618.98.text:
It's actually this number instead." Okay. So
be aware of that. The first time you write

624.20.text:
something down, they might change it, so
keep your ear out for that; listen for that.

630.85.text:
Number 11. One thing to practice is listening
to groups of numbers. Maybe you're good at

637.99.text:
listening to the number one, if I say: "five",
"seven", you understand that. But if I say

644.59.text:
a lot of numbers at the same time like: "My
phone number is 971-225" - it's not this,

652.64.text:
by the way, so don't call this number
- "1-877-43298". Okay. I hope nobody has this number. But if

665.38.text:
I say something like that, were you able to
write down all those numbers?" All right?

670.97.text:
You've got to get used to listening to
large groups of numbers in sequence.

677.32.text:
Again, about the numbers because you often
have to listen to something about numbers

681.63.text:
in the IELTS. It's also important to listen
for the difference between "13" and "30",

690.61.text:
"14" and "40", "15" and "50", and so on. Okay?
So the trick here is: "13", "teen" is usually

701.26.text:
louder, "thir" is quieter and shorter, versus:
"30" where "thir" is longer, "ty" is shorter.

711.82.text:
So get used to listening to these numbers so
you can actually hear the difference, because

716.02.text: you might hear that on the IELTS.

719.45.text:
Number 13, this is also very important. Your
handwriting must be clear. All right? If they

727.78.text:
can't read what you write, you're not going
to get the marks for your answer. Even if

731.59.text:
it's correct, if they can't read it - that's a problem.
So if you have bad handwriting,

738.17.text:
this is something you should work on. Practice writing.
Start off slow and then work on speed;

744.92.text:
get better and better and better, and faster at writing.
All right? So write well.

750.97.text:
Number 14, this is my last tip of the day. With...
Again, this is with spelling because

757.99.text:
it's so important on the IELTS for the listening section.
One thing they often do is they'll

764.01.text:
have somebody spell something out. So maybe they'll...
Someone will be on the phone and

769.45.text:
they'll say their last name. "My last name
is Tattoli." Okay? And then they'll spell

778.53.text:
it. "That's T-a-t-t-o-l-i." Now, one thing to
be careful of is often times they do these

787.07.text:
double lettering thing where when
they're on the phone, they'll say:

791.81.text:
"It's T-a- double 't'-o-l-i." This means there are two "t's".
So if you hear the word: "double", "double

801.56.text:
't'", "double 'm'", "double 'n'". My name has
a double "m". Be aware of that. It means

809.32.text:
you have to write down two of those.
All right?

813.02.text:
So I know you are going to do well on this test.
It's... It's... You can do it. It's

820.22.text:
all a matter of practice, practice, practice.
All right? And just constantly practicing

826.22.text:
to improve. So you can do it, I know you can,
and you need to know you can do it. It's very

832.15.text: important to be confident in yourself.

834.64.text:
So, for a lot of extra language learning material,
you can come visit our website at www.engvid.com.

843.34.text:
Also, there's another great website: www.GoodLuckIELTS.com.
On our website, I will have a quiz to test

852.01.text:
you on some of these tips to see if you remember them.
So, until next time, take care.
